data.text: Draghi: The popularity of the euro has never been so high

and [it has been] the main ingredient in the success of the ECB in being a credible central bank and in the big changes that the ECB has had. We ought to be very, very grateful to our standing staff (2/2)
Draghi: The quality of our deliberations owes so much to the quality of our staff. That's the main ingredient of everything we've done .... (1/2)
@MKTWgoldstein @isabelschnabel Corrected in the meantime
Draghi: @Isabel_Schnabel is an excellent economist. She has all the capacities to do very, very well. We should welcome her nomination very warmly.
Draghi: This experience as president of the ECB has been intense, profound, and fascinating.
Draghi: With fiscal policy, the monetary policy objective will be reached sooner with less side-effects
Draghi: If one wants to see higher rates sooner, fiscal policy should be active
Draghi: On the gift [Prusssian helmet] I received in March 2012, there is an old German saying: Geschenkt ist geschenkt. I plan to keep it.
Draghi: If there is one thing that I'm proud of then it is that we have always pursued our mandate. Never give up.
Draghi: How do I feel? I feel like someone who tried to comply with the mandate in the best possible way.
Draghi: Central banks ought to continue to cooperate within their mandate and fora like the G20 are more important than ever
Draghi: Unfortunately everything that has happened since September has shown abundantly that the Governing Council's determination to act was justified
Draghi: The lower likelihood of a hard Brexit has improved the situation, but the uncertainty is still there
Draghi: The main risk is a downturn in the economy, whether it is global or in the euro zone
Draghi: The overall assessment of negative rates is positive. The improvements in the economy have more than offset the negative side effects.

Draghi: Governments with fiscal space should act in an effective and timely manner. In countries where public debt is high, governments need to pursue prudent policies and meet structural balance targets.
Draghi: In order to reap the full benefits from our monetary policy measures, other policy areas must contribute more decisively
Draghi: The growth of loans to firms and households remained solid, benefiting from the continued pass-through of our accommodative monetary policy stance to bank lending rates
Draghi: While labour cost pressures have strengthened amid tighter labour markets, the weaker growth momentum is delaying their pass-through to inflation
Draghi: The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook remain on the downside
Draghi: The package will support the euro area expansion, the ongoing build-up of domestic price pressures and, thus, the sustained convergence of inflation to our medium-term inflation aim
Draghi: The comprehensive package of our last meeting provides substantial monetary stimulus, which will contribute to a further easing in borrowing conditions for firms and households

Draghi: Incoming data since the meeting in September confirm our previous assessment of a protracted weakness in euro area growth dynamics, the persistence of prominent downside risks and muted inflation pressures

Draghi: The Governing Council continues to stand ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation moves towards its aim in a sustained manner, in line with its commitment to symmetry
Draghi: The Governing Council’s forward guidance will ensure that financial conditions adjust in accordance with changes to the inflation outlook

Draghi: The Governing Council reiterated the need for a highly accommodative stance of monetary policy for a prolonged period of time to support underlying inflation pressures and headline inflation developments over medium term

Draghi: We intend to continue reinvesting, in full, the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the APP for an extended period of time past the date when we start raising the key ECB interest rates
Draghi: We expect net purchases to run for as long as necessary to reinforce the accommodative impact of our policy rates, and to end shortly before we start raising the key ECB interest rates
Draghi: … and until such convergence has been consistently reflected in underlying inflation dynamics (2/2)

Draghi: We expect ECB interest rates to remain at present or lower levels until we have seen the inflation outlook robustly converge to a level sufficiently close to, but below, 2% within our projection horizon… (1/2)

As part of #GlobalEthicsDay, we heard from Mihails Kozlovs from @EUAuditors about their special report on the ethical frameworks of EU institutions, and Rosita Hickey from the @EUombudsman, who shared the Ombudsman’s views on integrity and good governance for public institutions. https://t.co/zRYbEyTacz

Among the measures we take to ensure we work with integrity:
✅ All staff receive ethics training
✅ Our Ethics Framework and Code of Conduct are publicly available
✅ A dedicated Compliance and Governance Office advises staff

Learn more https://t.co/N4PxJU5R9K

Today is #GlobalEthicsDay. We at the ECB are committed to performing our duties impartially and with integrity every day. To promote good corporate governance and the highest ethical standards, we team up with national central banks and banking supervisors. https://t.co/U2qkLdu3uI

The gender gap in economics persists. We want to talk about solutions to address this issue. Watch live on our website for an in-depth panel discussion and key speeches by Iris Bohnet (Harvard) and Andy Haldane (Bank of England). Find out more https://t.co/TsbLnZlgqh https://t.co/3nOQBwKdQx

But a lot remains to be done: women are still less likely than men to apply for promotion and are still under-represented in top positions. Find out more in our recent working paper https://t.co/F2CLPdvlU2

Draghi: Nei dibattiti sul futuro dell’Europa si discute sempre meno se la sua esistenza abbia senso e assai di più sulla via migliore per avanzare. Su queste basi la nostra Unione può durare e prosperare. 

L’intervento presso @UniCatt è disponibile qui: https://t.co/wQbU4qbvuj

Draghi: Sono ottimista sul futuro dell’Europa. Penso che col tempo essere parte dell’UE e dell’Unione monetaria sia diventato normale per gran parte dei cittadini. L’euro è più popolare che mai; il sostegno all’UE tocca i valori più alti registrati dall’inizio della crisi.
Draghi: Il riconoscimento dell’estensione e dei limiti del nostro mandato comporta l’obbligo di parlare chiaramente quando necessario e di spiegare le opzioni disponibili.

Draghi: Aver ricevuto il nostro mandato da politici designati dalla volontà dei cittadini ha alcune implicazioni essenziali: non abbiamo la libertà di decidere se dobbiamo fare ciò che è necessario fare per assolvere il nostro mandato. È nostro dovere farlo.

Draghi: L’umiltà discende dalla consapevolezza che il potere e la responsabilità del servitore pubblico non sono illimitati ma derivano dal mandato conferito che guida le sue decisioni e pone limiti alla sua azione.

Draghi: Durante la crisi il coraggio di agire venne dalla convinzione che i rischi sarebbero stati maggiori se non avessimo fatto nulla. Non agendo saremmo venuti meno al nostro mandato e avremmo potuto mettere a rischio l’integrità della moneta che dovevamo preservare.

Draghi: Una volta stabilito nella misura del possibile come stanno i fatti arriva il momento della decisione. La tentazione di non decidere è frequente. È in questo momento che il policy maker deve far leva sul CORAGGIO.

Draghi sulla CONOSCENZA: Il policy maker non può appoggiarsi alla realtà empirica allo stesso modo di uno scienziato ma può utilizzare lo stesso approccio, analizzando l’esperienza e verificando le ipotesi adottate, per rispondere meglio alle richieste dei cittadini.

Ispirandosi al suo mandato alla BCE, ai banchieri centrali, ai funzionari dello Stato e ai politici con cui ha lavorato, Mario Draghi riflette su tre aspetti che caratterizzano un buon policy maker: conoscenza, coraggio e umiltà. https://t.co/Z4hsqbA1W7

@Unicatt Draghi: Debates and critiques about the future of Europe are now less about whether it should exist, and more about how best to take it forward. That is a solid basis for our union to endure and, ultimately, to thrive.

Read the full speech here https://t.co/aQuBL7TwBJ
@Unicatt Draghi: Understanding the scope and confines of our mandate imparts another obligation: to speak up when necessary and explain the available options.

@Unicatt Draghi: The fact that our mandate comes from elected officials has significant implications. It means that we are not at liberty to decide whether we should do what is necessary to deliver this mandate. It is our duty to do so.

@Unicatt Draghi: HUMILITY comes from the recognition that the power and responsibility held by public servants are not boundless, but are derived from the mandate conferred on them, which provides the guidance for decision-making and sets the limits of action.

@Unicatt Draghi: What gave us the courage to act during the crisis was the conviction that there was a far greater risk if we did nothing. Inaction would have meant nothing less than the failure of our mandate and, potentially, of the currency we had been tasked with preserving.

@Unicatt Draghi: Once the facts have been established as best they can, then comes the decision to act. It is often tempting not to make a decision at all. But this is precisely the point at which policymakers must draw on the second quality: COURAGE.

@Unicatt Draghi on KNOWLEDGE: Policymakers can never benefit from the same degree of empiricism as scientists, but they can employ the same approach of examining the evidence and testing hypotheses in order to better meet the demands that people place on government.

(THREAD) Mario Draghi reflects on three qualities that make a good policymaker: knowledge, courage and humility. His speech at @UniCatt draws on his term at the ECB and experience before that interacting with other central bankers, public officials and political figures. https://t.co/TXRG8ww84V
